ExtractionIntro1
10 grams of dry spinach leaves were weighed. (Any stems and veins were removed from the leaves before weighing).
Place them in a mortar.
Prepare 10 mL of a mixture of solvents viz. acetone and hexane, in the ratio 50:50 in a measuring flask.
The mixture of solvents is poured in small lots into the mortar and the spinach leaves are crushed well till it becomes a nice paste.
Take a 50 ml clean conical flask.
Place a filter funnel on the mouth of the flask.
Plug in a small piece of cotton as shown.
Pour the paste into the conical flask through the funnel.
The dark green filtrate will contain the crude mixture of plant pigments.
Now remove the filter funnel.
Add about 5gm of Anhydrous Sodium Sulfate into the flask using a spatula and swirl it.
The Anhydrous Sodium Sulfate will absorb the traces of water and settle down at the bottom of the flask.
Take a fresh conical flask.
A funnel with a cotton plug was placed on the mouth of the flask as shown earlier.
The crude extract is poured into the flask through the funnel so that the hydrated sodium sulfate will be filtered off.
Now remove the funnel.
About 3g of silica gel (for column chromatography, 60-120 mesh) was added to the flask so that the crude extract is adsorbed on the silica gel.
The traces of solvent remaining in the flask are removed gently using a hair dryer to make the material free-flowing.
Take a weighing paper.
The silica to which the material is adsorbed is transferred into it.
Take a column; plug in a small piece of cotton.
Use a wood applicator to tamp down the cotton.
The column is clamped to a stand.
About 25 g of fresh silica gel (for column chromatography, 60-120 mesh) was taken in a beaker.
Add 100mL of hexane into the beaker containing silica gel, to make it slurry.
Stir it well using a glass rod.
The slurry is now poured into the column.
Now the crude pigment adsorbed on silica gel is slowly added to the top of the column.
About 500 mL of hexane is added slowly from the top of the column in lots so that the non-polar beta-carotene which is soluble in hexane will dissolve and start moving down along with hexane.
The solvent will now flow out through the stop cock, leaving a uniform packing of silica gel inside the column. Care should be taken to close the stop cock just before the level of solvent in the column falls below the silica layer (If the silica gel in the column dries up, the efficiency of the column will be affected).
The dissolved beta-carotene will move down the column as a yellow band. Elution with hexane is continued till this band reaches the bottom of the column.
Turn off the stop cock when the yellow colour layer reaches at the bottom of the column.
Another conical flask is placed below the column and the fraction of hexane containing the yellow colour pigment is collected. Elution is continued till the yellow band of beta-carotene elutes out completely. Close the stop cock and replace the conical flask at the bottom with a fresh one.
Now take about 500 mL of acetone in a conical flask . Pour it slowly into the column and turn on the stop cock.
Now acetone will move down the column and will carry the dissolved chlorophyll along with it as a green band.
Now acetone will move down the column and will carry the dissolved chlorophyll along with it as a green band.
Close the stop cock when the green colour band reaches at the bottom of the column.
Replace the conical flask with a fresh one and now turn on the stop cock again. Continue elution with acetone till the green band completely moves out of the column.
Stop elution when there is no more green band left in the column.
Take a round bottom flask (RB flask).
Pour the contents of the conical flask containing beta-carotene into the RB flask.
The solvent hexane from this RB Flask is now removed using a Rotary Evaporator; For this, the RB flask is connected to the holder of the rotary evaporator as shown.
The solvent hexane from this RB Flask is now removed using a Rotary Evaporator; For this, the RB flask is connected to the holder of the rotary evaporator as shown.
Slowly bring the flask down into contact with the heating water bath.
Turn on the rotary evaporator; the flask starts rotating within the heating bath.
After sometime, we can see that the hexane from the RB flask is collected in the receiving flask connected to the condenser of the rotary evaporator, leaving behind a yellowish-orange powder in the RB flask in the heating bath.
After sometime, we can see that the hexane from the RB flask is collected in the receiving flask connected to the condenser of the rotary evaporator, leaving behind a yellowish-orange powder in the RB flask in the heating bath.
The yellowish-orange powder is transferred carefully into a watch glass.
Repeat the same procedure for green solvent as well. Take a round bottom flask (RB flask).
Pour the green acetone fraction containing chlorophyll into the RB flask.
Keep it in a Rotary Evaporator; fix the RB flask in the holder as shown.
Keep it in a Rotary Evaporator; fix the RB flask in the holder as shown.
Slowly bring the flask down into the heating bath.
Turn on the rotary evaporator; the flask starts rotating within the heating bath.
After sometime, acetone will evaporate and gets collected in the receiving flask connected to the condenser of the rotary evaporator. A green powder is left in the RB flask in the heating bath.
After sometime, acetone will evaporate and gets collected in the receiving flask connected to the condenser of the rotary evaporator. A green powder is left in the RB flask in the heating bath.
Carefully transfer this green powder into a watch glass.
Here, the yellowish-orange powder is beta-carotene and green is Chlorophyll.
The yellowish-orange pigment beta-carotene is soluble in hexane whereas the green pigment chlorophyll is soluble in acetone. Therefore these pigments can be eluted successfully by the column chromatography of their crude extract with these solvents in a sequential manner.
